Award.AwardTitle: Earth-abundant Metal Catalysts for the Functionalization of Strong Carbon-Hydrogen Bonds
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Thomas R. Cundari of the University of North Texas to use advanced scientific computing to understand the chemistry of "green" metal catalysts. "Green" replacements for precious metals catalysts are increasingly sought by the scientific and industrial communities as concerns grow for the geopolitical realities, high costs and ecological issues associated with these metals. In considering catalytic chemistry alternatives, advanced scientific computing permits the comparative study of economical, earth-abundant metals with oft-employed expensive, rare transition metals. The goal is to establish the proper computational tools, such that these metals might be compared as catalyst candidates with some level of predictability. Particular emphasis is being given to catalysts for formation of bonds between the elements of carbon and nitrogen as well as carbon and oxygen, which are important reactions for transforming hydrocarbon resources from petroleum and natural gas into more valuable chemical compounds. Students participating in this project are receiving cutting edge training for future careers in the STEM workforce.

Professor Cundari is performing computational chemistry studies on potential earth-abundant catalysts based upon metals from the middle transition series. The research project is focusing on catalysts for the activation and functionalization of hydrocarbons, especially those found in natural gas. The essential chemical characteristics that determine the preferred pathway carbon-hydrogen bond activation and subsequent carbon-X (X = nitrogen or oxygen) bond formation (functionalization) are being investigated. Of particular interest are the studies of several promising new classes of transition metal complexes, including those for which carbon-hydrogen bond activation can be triggered by coordination of a Lewis base.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CHE-1464943 placed emphasis on the chemistry of Earth-abundant metals as cheaper, more “green” replacements for current precious metal industrial catalysts. In essence we seek to exploit so-called redox non-innocent ligands to “ennoble” base metals. Our students’ research utilizes state-of-the-art computational chemistry to aid experimental efforts in the catalysis community. Development, testing, and application of improved computational modeling for metals and integration of our students’ research with that of leading experimentalists in the catalysis community define additional intellectual contributions of CHE-1464943. Training students to succeed as independent scientists is the core of our group’s ethos, and essential in preparing the technical workforce for the future. The scientific publications that describe the research conducted with NSF support are the fruits of hard work by 3 high school, 2 undergraduate and 8 PhD students in our group. Also, PhD students of our many experimental collaborators learn computational chemistry, incorporate modeling into their dissertations, and enhance their mastery of computational chemistry via collaborations sponsored by CHE-1464943. To date, sixteen (16) refereed scientific publications in leading scientific journals acknowledge CHE-1464943. All of the scientific papers are lead-authored by junior scientists; students in our group handle the entire submission process, including referee rebuttal. For the majority of these early-career researchers, the papers below are the litany of their first scientific endeavors, and a key stepping stone to future career success in science and technical fields. Numerous talks by the principal investigator further disseminated the results of this NSF sponsored research, and much of this work appeared in the dissertations of the graduate students, forming an important part of their graduate research endeavors. Major breakthroughs enabled by support of CHE-1464943 impacted metal catalysis and inorganic/organometallic chemistry, chemical disciplines that are essential to understanding the processes by which abundant domestic resources can be converted into more valuable consumer products.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2020
Modified by: Thomas R Cundari
